Riddle of the Week · Vol. 347
Walter's Weekly Conundrum

"Three threads enter a mutex. One carries truth, one carries garbage, and one carries the hopes of a Series B that should never have been funded. The garbage collector sleeps. The truth waits. The hopes? They were already dead. Which thread exits first, and why is it always the wrong one?"

Our Services

Quantum Optimization
Through Applied Plumbing Theory

Every system is a pipe. Every bug is a leak. We find the leaks. Then we speak about them cryptically until you figure it out yourself. That's the process.

The Zeno

$47.99/month — You'll never quite reach full optimization

Our entry-level paradox package. We analyze your codebase and tell you what's wrong, but only in the form of increasingly specific limericks. Each limerick gets you 50% closer to the answer. You never fully arrive. That's the point.

Includes: 4 limericks/month · 1 interpretive dance consultation (15 min, Bulgarian folk music provided) · Email support (responses in riddle form, 72-hour SLA)

The Fermi

$199.99/month — Approximately correct, give or take

Our mid-tier estimation package. We estimate how many bugs are in your system using back-of-envelope calculations performed on actual envelopes. Walter personally licks each envelope shut. The estimates are surprisingly accurate. The envelopes smell like copper fittings.

Includes: Everything in Zeno · 12 limericks/month · 2 interpretive dance sessions (30 min each) · Priority riddle hotline · 1 feline QA audit per quarter

The Grandfather

$849.99/month — Go back in time and prevent the bug from being born

Our enterprise paradox tier. We embed a consultant (Walter, wearing a tinfoil hat) in your office for one week per month. He will wander your halls muttering about "the interconnectedness of all sewage systems" and occasionally fixing critical production bugs by accident while looking for the bathroom.

Includes: Everything in Fermi · Unlimited limericks · Walter on-site (travel + tinfoil hat expenses billed separately) · Weekly feline QA audits · Chairman Meow's personal cell number (he will not answer)
The Board of Directors

Quality Assurance
Is Not a Democracy

Each board member holds absolute veto power over all project deliverables. Appeals may be submitted in writing, but will be sat upon.

Chairman Meow

Chief Executive Inspector · Ginger Tabby · Age 7

With golden eyes that pierce through code,
He sits upon his velvet throne,
No project ships without his nod,
No blue shall live — this much is known.
He once rejected Stripe's whole stack.

Vetoes to date: 847 · Approval rate: 3.1% · Known bias: Rejects anything involving the color blue, rounded corners, or "vibes-based architecture"

Sergeant Whiskers

VP of Napping & Compliance · Tuxedo · Age 4

In black and white, she judges all,
Each semicolon, bracket, brace,
She sleeps through sprints but wakes to find
A missing null check, out of place.
Her naps last longer than your standups.

Vetoes to date: 312 · Approval rate: 11% · Known bias: Automatically rejects any PR submitted between 2-4 PM (nap time). Also dislikes Comic Sans and anyone named "Kevin."

Professor Beans

Director of Existential Risk · Calico · Age 12

The eldest sage upon the board,
Her gaze has seen frameworks rise and fall,
She knew that Angular would wane,
She warned of PHP. She warned of all.
Nobody listened. Beans remembers.

Vetoes to date: 2,341 · Approval rate: 0.4% · Known bias: Rejects everything. Has approved exactly 9 projects in her career. Three were blank documents. The others were pictures of fish.

Lieutenant Fluffington III

Head of Morale & Destruction · Maine Coon · Age 2

A gentle giant, soft of paw,
Who loves to knock things off the desk,
Your laptop, coffee, hopes, and dreams,
He'll swat them all — he thinks it's best.
He ate a USB drive once. It shipped.

Vetoes to date: 54 · Approval rate: 67% · Known bias: Approves everything he can physically sit on. Rejects anything stored exclusively in the cloud. "If I can't nap on it, it doesn't exist."

The Walter Method™

How an Engagement Works

Refined over 27 years. Questioned by many. Understood by none. Effective 93% of the time (the other 7% were Kevin's fault).

1

The Summoning

You email Walter. Walter does not check email. Walter's email is monitored by Lieutenant Fluffington III, who occasionally bats the mouse across the keyboard and accidentally responds. If Fluffington replies, you have been accepted. If silence, try again during non-nap hours (there are no non-nap hours).

Average response time: 11 days. Fastest response: 3 minutes (Fluffington was chasing the cursor).
2

The Interpretive Dance Consultation

Walter arrives at your office in steel-toed boots and a tinfoil hat. He connects his phone to your conference room speakers and plays a curated playlist of Bulgarian folk music (heavy on the gaida, light on the kaval). He then performs an interpretive dance that represents your system architecture. The dance lasts between 45 minutes and 3 hours. There is no intermission. You may not look away.

Walter's dance has correctly identified 14 zero-day vulnerabilities, 3 embezzlement schemes, and 1 ghost in a server room in Duluth.
3

The Limerick Scoping Phase

Based on his dance findings, Walter crafts a bespoke limerick that defines your project scope. The limerick is your SOW. It is legally binding in 14 states and the territory of Guam. Example: "A database rotting in prod / had schemas that even God / would look at and cry / then silently die / your indexes, frankly, are odd."

Limerick accuracy rate: 97.2%. The 2.8% failure rate is attributed to projects involving Kevin.
4

The Feline Quality Assurance Audit

All deliverables are printed on A3 paper and laid on the floor of the Audit Chamber (Walter's garage). The four members of the Board of Directors are released. They walk across the papers. Pages they sit on are approved. Pages they ignore are sent back for revision. Pages they shred are deleted from version control permanently. There is no appeals process.

Chairman Meow once rejected an entire Kubernetes migration by falling asleep on the rollback plan. The client later admitted this was the correct call.
Frequently Asked Questions

You Have Questions.
Walter Has Riddles.

Is Walter actually a plumber?

+
Walter holds a Class 4 Master Plumber certification from the state of New York (currently suspended following the 1998 incident, which we are contractually forbidden from discussing). He also holds a certificate in "Quantum Thought Leadership" from an online university that no longer exists. Both qualifications are equally relevant to what we do here.

Why do the cats have veto power?

+
In Q3 2019, we ran a controlled experiment: for six months, project approvals were handled by a committee of three senior engineers. For the following six months, by the cats. Client satisfaction scores were 34% higher under feline governance. Bug escape rate dropped 61%. We haven't looked back. The engineers now report to Sergeant Whiskers. They seem happier.

What happened in 1998?

+
We are contractually forbidden from discussing the 1998 incident. What we can say is that it took place at the Northeast Regional Plumbing Convention in Syracuse, it involved a misdiagnosis of "existential dread" in a copper fitting, and Walter was asked to leave but was never technically banned. He maintains to this day that the fitting was, in fact, experiencing existential dread, and that history has vindicated him. The fitting was later found corroded from the inside. Draw your own conclusions.

Can I just get normal consulting without the riddles?

+
No. Walter physically cannot communicate in non-riddle form. We hired a speech therapist in 2021. She quit after three sessions, citing "an inability to determine whether the client was speaking in metaphor or describing an actual plumbing emergency." Walter described her departure as "the river that flows uphill eventually finds the sky." We're still not sure if that was a riddle or a threat.

Why does Chairman Meow hate the color blue?

+
We commissioned a veterinary behavioral study. The results were inconclusive but suggested it may be related to an early kittenhood trauma involving a blue yarn ball and a ceiling fan. What we know empirically is this: any deliverable containing the hex value #0000FF or anything within a 40-degree hue range of it will be immediately shredded. One client tried to sneak in a "midnight navy" (#191970). Chairman Meow knew. Chairman Meow always knows.

Who is Kevin?

+
Kevin was a junior developer who interned with us in the summer of 2022. In his first week, he committed directly to main, used !important on 47 CSS rules, named a variable data2_final_FINAL_v3, and fed Professor Beans a grape (grapes are toxic to cats; Beans is fine, but she has never forgiven him). Kevin now works at a Fortune 500 company. We do not speak his name. When something goes wrong, it is attributed to Kevin retroactively.

Do you have any actual technical credentials?

+
Walter can solder a copper pipe joint in 11 seconds. He once fixed a production database by "listening to it breathe" (he placed his ear against the server rack for forty minutes, then changed one index). He does not know what Kubernetes is, but he correctly predicted its market cap trajectory based on "the sound the word makes when you say it underwater." His LinkedIn lists his title as "Pipe Whisperer & Quantum Custodian." He has 12,000 followers. He has never posted.
